intro: Serapias occidentalis, commonly known as the western sandwort, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Rockcress (Capparaceae) and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming structure. The plant produces showy, yellow-orange flowers with five petals, typically blooming in spring. It thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as coastal dunes and cliffs. Serapias occidentalis is adapted to dry, sunny conditions and is considered a rare and specialized species.
